review_title: Avoid if you have other options
pros: Interesting studies and the ability to impact national (and global) policies. Good opportunity to work with world experts. Great colleagues (but not great leadership) who really care about their work and are both driven and intelligent.
cons:
Everything else. Particularly work-life balance.

With its soft-money business model, the Academies is increasingly stringing-along staff (particularly study directors with relatively new PhDs) on fast-track studies. Typical consensus studies take 1-2 years, and the Academies used to staff these sufficiently with research and administrative support. On the all to frequent fast-track model, most of the same red-tape is still present, and study directors are literally having panic attacks and seeing therapists, trying to deliver for a sponsor in 4-9 months. Senior leadership just doesn't seem to care, and views talent as expendable. Support has gone way down, with studies sharing research assistants, and the program officers (study directors) picking up all of the slack. 

If you are looking for long-term buy-in from an organization, look elsewhere! Program staff are contracted, and must look for a new study/project before the end of their study/project (or they will be let go). The Academies may divide your time (20% to one project, 40% to another, etc.) if you are able to find a new position, and you'll have to go wherever an opening is. As some say, if you are an expert in your field, this is where your "science career will come to die". It's sad, because the organization could offer so much - I hope that they rethink their business model and start supporting program staff through more than words.

review_title: Avoid like the plague! It used to be a good place
pros:
The Academies is renowned for the advice that it provides to the federal government and other organizations. You have an opportunity to make a real impact and policy change. It's a great opportunity to interact and become colleagues with the best and brightest in the fields of health and medicine.

In more junior positions such as Senior Program Asst., Research Asst., or Research Associate, the Academies is a great stepping stone to get into graduate or medical school.
cons:
The Academies is not what it used to be, especially as a Program Officer in HMD. As a program officer for a consensus study, your primary task is to work with a committee of experts and produce a report with the committee's recommendations. Much of that work, (writing, research, and meeting planning) if not all are taken on by the study director/program officer. There aren't enough hours in the day to get your job done, write a report and be a good manager--especially on a fast tracked timeline. 

Normally, consensus studies take 18-24 months, however HMD and others are cramming the work into 8 months! Sponsors want consensus studies turned around over night and instead of pushing back, the organization accepts the task and burns staff out trying to make the deadline. On top of this, there is insufficient staff support to help reach the goal. The overall business model is extremely flawed. 

Staff are overworked and underpaid. I've personally worked on federal holidays because the work had to still get done. There is literally no "work-life balance" and a 37.5 hr work week ends up being more like 50 + hrs a week.

review_title: A superb opportunity to engage world class professionals.
pros: As a post-doc at the National Academies I had the opportunity to meet and work with some of the giants of the scientific profession.  It would have literally taken me a lifetime via almost any other avenue.  This in of itself makes for valuable experience, but most satisfying, was the production of studies that were so tangibly impactful and widely cited.
cons: As an employee of the Academies you basically lord over a process of legitimacy.  The experts in the room are brought in on a pro bono basis by the Academy, which means that your job is not to contribute intellectually to the product, but rather guide the process.  As such, over time, you become an expert in that process rather than the subject matter of any given  report.  This can be a little frustrating at times particularly for those who are used to being involved in a more substantive capacity.

review_title: High job insecurity, high pay inequality
job_title: Senior Program Officer in Washington, DC
pros: If you get in with the right group at the Academies, you can have a real positive impact on national policy.  There is also feeling among staff that the Academies are above the board and work hard to produce (mostly) objective advice.
cons:
Nearly every position is on soft money, making the place feel more like a consulting company, but without the high pay.  Fund raising for studies is a constant activity.  

More senior staff were hired at a time when starting salaries were respectable.  Newer staff hired in the last 5 years or so are brought in at a much lower level and will have to work much longer to achieve the same salaries as the more senior people.  This creates a two-tier situation where the senor staff are happy and comfortable (they get first dibs on studies that come in), while newer staff will be living paycheck to paycheck for years.

review_title: A mixed bag, you never really know what you'll get
pros: You have the opportunity and access to some of the best and brightest minds in the world and said experts are willing and eager to do work for the Academies free of charge. While working with these experts you have the opportunity to learn much about the topic of the study.
cons: There is a ceiling at every turn. The opportunities for growth are severely limited and the situation got only worse as the recession crept in. The Academies is very proud of tradition and doing things "the way they have always done things", however being completely adverse to change and even fighting it every step of the way has proven detrimental to the organization and they are hemorrhaging both great talent as well as money.

review_title: Sinking ship
pros: Smart colleagues, cafeteria in both office locations
cons:
As an organization that promotes evidence based research and objectivity, hiring and promotion structures are at the will and politics of a board director rather than an employee’s performance. There’s a reason why certain boards see continual turn over and employees leave the organization after 2-3 years. We all are passionate about the mission, but lack of advancement or promotion is a serious concern. If you are a white male with moderate to average intelligence, you will do just fine and most likely thrive.
Tens of thousands of dollars were spent on a review of the organization. Unfortunately it seems that leadership isn’t serious about implementing any of the changes that help to make the organization on par with other non profits in DC.

review_title: Institute of Medicine (IOM)-Not as good as I thought
pros: Great Benefits. I love the benefits and some of the colleagues. Periods where work is challenging. Have some cool projects. Best part of my day: Interaction with junior staff
cons: Its not what you think and expect. Work is repetitive and can at times be boring. The staff pretty much serve as the middle person between scientist (called committees) who do the work, and the publications. The senior staff and executive officers have a lot of favoritism. If you are liked, you will go far, if not, then you are stuck in the same position for more than 10 years. There is something wrong with an organization when the majority of the staff are waiting for better opportunities to show up in different organizations so they can leave. Inconsistent in terms of promotions and raise. It is a very bourgeois environment. A lot of gossip in the office by both staff and executive (are we still in high school?).

review_title: Tolerates bullying of staff, does not listen to its own reports
job_title: Senior Program Officer in Washington, DC

cons: The organization as a whole lacks diversity in race/ethnicity. While more balanced in terms of gender, many of the positions of leadership do not promote women or non-binary individuals. There mandatory reporting around diversity, equity, and inclusion doesn't reflect the evidence-based reports that they produce. The staff are subjected to bullying and harassment from prestigious volunteers, sponsors, and staff notably those who are younger and women. Many of the institution's protocols and processes are mean to shield the institution from liability and negative attention, rather than advance the evidence.

review_title: Middle Earth with Email
pros: Exposure to lots of smart people doing lots of smart things. If you like an academic research setting, this is the place.
cons:
The only difference between the current National Academy of Sciences and any organization from the 1800s is the current organization uses email. 

Employees fit into two categories: (1) senior management/research staff and (2) support staff. There is nothing in between, therefore there are no "ladders" to climb. You are either a phd (or semi-phd) employee doing rigorous research or you are dealing with the tedious administrative work that goes into helping those projects get carried out.  This isn't really a con, but just an observation of the organizational structure.

review_title: Not ideal and predictably about the bottom line

cons: Lack of transparency. Failure to recognize success of staff. Hierarchical and not at all collaborative. Staff expertise not valued or welcomed until it matters. Tight budgets, inflexible staffing structures, inconsistent policies throughout the entire organization. Administrative professionals are overworked and underpaid, and expectations/demands for these professionals are high despite existing barriers.  Gaslighting is not unheard of. Diversity across race, ethnicity, gender, sexual orientation, etc. in senior staff and committee membership is limited.

review_title: Potential for impactful work, but pressure for shorter-term projects
pros: Fantastic colleagues! Interesting work. Projects have the potential to affect national policy.
cons: 1) This is a contract research organization, so funding ebbs and flows and layoffs are not uncommon. 2) There is increasing pressure to do shorter and shorter projects, which is unfortunate. 3) Commitment to quality differs hugely across the organization, as does the quality of management.

review_title: Couldnt leave fast enough, no one lasts more than a year!

review_title: This is not for College Graduates
pros: There is nothing positive in working at this organization
cons:
I did not enjoy my time with this company. The jobs are all outsourced through a temp agency, Randstad. None of the jobs are permanent and the National Academies 100 percent heavily relies on a temp agency for employment. The department I worked in and the National Academies itself didn't utilize my skill set and my work experience all of which was in a different career field. The National Academies were strictly taking advantage of me and "using" me for office administration jobs such as writing and creating documents using Microsoft Office suite, setting up and conducting weekly meetings, paying financial bills such as wireless phone services, and food, and filing. I was told this was an administrative assistant position with the telecommunications department, but it was really a Telecom Analyst job requiring 7 years of experience. The same tasks are found in Senior Program/Project Assistant, Project Assistant, and Program Assistant, Data entry/Administrative Assistant, Senior Project Assistant,  Database Assistant, Data Entry Clerk, and many other jobs.

Also, the staff in all of the departments within the National Academies do not acknowledge nor take notice of temporary employee. All of them treat temporary employees like a piece of dirt and second-class citizens. They don't really care about temporary employees and ridicule them. They just replace temporary employees whenever they want and do not care about what happens to them. There are no permanent jobs for temporary employees especially those coming from a temp agency. None of the employment positions on the National Academies website is entry-level. It is 100 percent mid-level or senior-level jobs requiring 4 to 10 years of experience.

The National Academies is very stuck in a rut in using a temp agency to find employees for vacant and open employment positions.

The job positions, duties/responsibilities, and skillset have 100 percent nothing to do with my skillset. The National Academies are simply negative using and taking negative advantage of temporary employees on a regular basis 365 days a year.

College Graduates and recent college graduates, do not work with the National Academies at all. They will not help you with your career endeavors/career goals and will not care about you.

review_title: No way up, no way out
pros: Benefits, collegial co-workers, diversity of topics to work on, engagement with senior stakeholders in multiple policy areas
cons:
And...that about it. Yes, you will have the change to work on numerous "cool projects" and engage with influential stakeholders. However, given the structure of the work of The National Academies, you as an employee will either become an events manager or implementer of the expert guidance of stakeholders. 

This could use some explanation. The primary types of projects at The National Academies are: Consensus Studies or Forums/Roundtables. 

For consensus studies, you will have a unique opportunity to take a deep dive into a contentious policy issue. While you might have some creative independence in what to research or how to structure arguments, the intellectual thrust of the studies are drive by a committee of experts that you help recruit. It can be said that by helping structure the committee, you are influencing the perspectives that inform the study.  But this ignores a severe weakness of the organization. As a membership-driven organization, expert committees are required to draft at least one or two members. Furthermore, given the processes that studies are driven by, there is undue preference to select those who have previously served on committees. This leads to the projects being informed by a revolving door of experts, with little to no recruitment of newer expertise or perspectives.

The second type of projects are those conducted by Forums and Roundtables - primarily workshops. These are 1 to 1.5 day symposiums in which experts are recruited to discuss a particular topic. The topic that is being discussed is almost always driven by input from members of Forums and Roundtables. This is good in some ways - the main one being that the topic at hand is immediately relevant to the policy space. The downside is that you as an employee will have little opportunities to learn how to identify vital issues in the field as the onus of identifying topics is on the membership. Once a topic is identified, you will once again recruit an expert committee to conceptualize an agenda and identify speakers to invite.  While there may be some opportunities for staff to inform the agenda, it is once again predominantly driven by the experts. Thus, staff are left to the thankless of job of implementing the expert committee's wishes, with few opportunities to learn why the decision was arrived at. 

TL; DR - the main skill you will gain is facilitation. Yes, you will gain exposure to a lot of topics, but your knowledge will be a mile wide, but an inch deep. You will not gain quantitative skills and will barely gain qualitative skills. This is a disastrous recipe to showcase any accomplishments for a job elsewhere. 

In short stay away. I looked passed negative reviews when I accepted my position here. Don't make the same mistake.

review_title: No M.S.? No PhD? Don't bother. You won't be allowed to go anywhere.
pros: Decent benefits, nice facilities, and opportunities to network (though if you're admin, you will be discouraged from talking to committee members about anything other than food services and their hotel stay).
cons:
Senior leadership across divisions look down on anyone who does not have a M.S. or a PhD. The Academies does basic to moderately complex project management--a PhD is unnecessary to fulfill most roles at the Academies. And yet they treat anyone who does not have a higher degree as though they are lacking. Do I expect someone fresh out of undergrad to run a study and wrangle high level volunteer experts? No. But did I believe an institution that prides itself on advising the nation on things like diversity and inclusion and workforce empowerment to treat their own employees like they do? Also no. If you do not have a M.S. or PhD, you will not get anywhere. The only exception to this is of course if you're well liked--they can and will make exceptions for anyone who has schmoozed the right people. If you're looking at NASEM and they're offering you an SPA role and your hope is to one day work your way over into the science/program track (i.e., the people doing the work and getting paid an actual salary), do yourself a favor and don't take it. If you can, find yourself a research assistant position instead. You'll likely have to do some administrative work but you will be in the program track as a Research Assistant which means you might have a shot at doing work that requires the use of your brain. I didn't mind doing admin work and I didn't mind putting in my time and paying my dues but I never would have taken the job had I known that once you've been labeled as "admin" you will never be allowed to do anything else. 

Admin personnel work very hard--there is a ton of work to be done at that level. You will be expected to work long hours and you will be pressured to underreport your time because they don't want to pay OT to admin personnel. Program staff, on the other hand, are paid exorbitant salaries and can take 2 hour lunches, leave to hang out with their children, work at home as much as they want, and treat everyone else like garbage--all for a premium salary. The Academies value degrees over competent employees. Hard working support staff will never come close to being paid what people in the program track make. 

Racism and sexism also run rampant. If you dare to speak up you will be stripped of the responsibilities you do enjoy and you will be treated worse. Being sexually harassed? Bullied? Is someone treating you badly because you're not white? Are you being asked to underreport hours worked--essentially working for free when you're hardly paid anything to begin with? DONT go to HR. They work for NASEM. They are NOT there to protect you and what you say WILL get back to your superiors. They may not be able to fire you but boy will you have a target on your back. 

If you decide to take a job here, understand that the only benefit will be the NASEM name on your resume when you go to get another job.
